entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 21 at 9:30PM EDT until August 24 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Florida...
Suwannee River near Manatee Springs affecting Dixie and Levy Counties.
Suwannee River at Rock Bluff near Bell (CR 340) affecting Gilchrist, Dixie and Lafayette Counties.
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Suwannee River near Wilcox (US 19) affecting Gilchrist, Dixie and Levy Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Suwannee River near Wilcox (US 19).
* WHEN...Until Saturday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, In Gilchrist County, water floods much of SW County Road 344 West of SW 80th avenue. In Dixie County, homes on Water Street at Pervis Landing are inaccessible. Flooding begins at the Suwannee River RV Park.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 PM EDT Wednesday the stage was 10.4 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:30 PM EDT Wednesday was 10.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 10.5 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage Saturday morning. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 10.4 feet on 04/20/1980. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Dixie, FL; Gilchrist, FL; Levy, FL

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 21 at 9:30PM EDT until August 26 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Florida...
Suwannee River near Manatee Springs affecting Dixie and Levy Counties.

* WHERE...Suwannee River near Manatee Springs.
* WHEN...Until early Monday morning.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 21 at 7:22PM MDT until August 21 at 9:30PM MDT by NWS Cheyenne WY
entry.summary:
FFWCYS
The National Weather Service in Cheyenne has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Eastern Banner County in the panhandle of Nebraska... Northwestern Cheyenne County in the panhandle of Nebraska... Northeastern Kimball County in the panhandle of Nebraska... Southwestern Morrill County in the panhandle of Nebraska...
* Until 930 PM MDT.
* At 722 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1.25 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. The expected rainfall rate is 1 to 1.5 inches in 2 hours. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Redington, Harrisburg, Courthouse And Jail Rock and Morrill County Fairgrounds.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 21 at 6:16PM MST until August 22 at 12:30AM MST by NWS Flagstaff AZ
entry.summary:
FFWFGZ
The National Weather Service in Flagstaff has extended the
* Flash Flood Warning for... Coconino County in north central Arizona...
* Until 1230 AM MST /130 AM MDT/ Thursday.
* At 612 PM MST /712 PM MDT/, Heavy rain has ended across the Canyon Diablo Wash. Between 2 and 4 inches of rain have fallen near Interstate-40 but further upstream 3 to 5 inches of rainfall were estimated by radar. It will take some time for the flood wave to reach the Little Colorado River. Be advised, flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Life-threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Life-threatening flash flooding of low-water crossings, creeks, normally dry washes and roads.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Canyon Diablo, Leupp and Sunrise.
This includes the following highways... Interstate 40 between mile markers 225 and 228. State Route 99 near mile marker 71.
This includes the following creeks, washes and rivers... Canyon Diablo Wash, Yellow Jacket Canyon, Diablo, Canyon, San Francisco Wash, Little Colorado River and Babbitt Wash.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 21 at 9:07PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...

At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47. At 20.0 feet, Access to homes on Santa Fe Road below SW Riverside Avenue becomes restricted in Columbia. Flooding begins on Santa Fe and Wilson Springs Road. At 21.0 feet, Homes are surrounded on River Run Road in Suwannee County. Structures flood along Santa Fe Road west of Idaho Parkway in Columbia County. At 22.0 feet, River Run Road at 29th loop floods in Suwannee County. Santa Fe Road in Columbia County is inaccessible.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued August 21 at 8:05PM EDT until August 22 at 12:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary:

* WHERE...Coastal New Hanover County.

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued August 21 at 2:37PM AKDT until August 22 at 6:00AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* LOCATION...The northern Kuskokwim Delta coast from the communities of Newtok south to Kipnuk.
* WAVES AND SURF...Water levels are expected to rise during high tide to 1 to 3 feet above the normal highest tide line. Waves heights of 4 to 8 feet by the coast.
* TIMING...Waves and surf will peak this afternoon during high tide. For Newtok, a secondary peak will be possible with the high tide on Thursday morning.
* IMPACTS...High surf may inundate or move property along the shoreline. Localized beach erosion is possible. There is potential for elevated water levels to persist Friday due to a long duration of westerly to southwesterly winds in conjunction with multiple high tide cycles.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 21 at 3:53PM CDT by NWS Shreveport LA
entry.summary:
AQASHV

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 21 at 3:34PM CDT by NWS New Orleans LA
entry.summary:
The Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality is forecasting an Ozone Advisory Day for Orleans, Jefferson, St John the Baptist, St Charles, St Bernard, St Tammany, and Plaquemines Parishes tomorrow.
The Air Quality Index indicates that ozone will be at the Orange level, which is unhealthy for sensitive groups. Increasing ozone levels may cause unhealthy air quality during afternoon hours. Active children and adults, the elderly, and people with respiratory diseases such as asthma should avoid prolonged outdoor exertion.
Please take whatever voluntary steps you can to reduce emissions that contribute to ozone formation. Drive less and make sure your automobile is in good working condition. Make sure your gas cap is tight. Wait until after 6 PM to refuel your vehicle and use gas powered lawn equipment. More information about current air quality and what you can do to help prevent ozone formation is available at the D E Q website www.deq.louisiana.gov/enviroflash or by calling 8 6 6 8 9 6 5 3 3 7.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued August 21 at 1:15PM PDT until August 22 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
A strong storm system for this time of the year will move into the area Thursday bringing moderate to strong winds. Because the best chance for precipitation will remain west of the Cascades, relative humidities will be low and this in combination with winds could result in critical conditions.
The National Weather Service in Medford has replaced the Fire Weather Watch to a Red Flag Warning which is in effect from 11 AM to 8 PM PDT Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Strong winds combined with critically low relative humidity can lead to the rapid growth and spread of new and existing fires. Outdoor burning is banned during fire season.
* AFFECTED AREA...The eastern half of Fire Weather Zone 285, this includes Alturas. The eastern part of part of Fire weather zone 625, this includes Adel and Alkali Lake.
* WIND...Southwest winds 20 to 30 mph with gusts 35 to 40 mph.
* HUMIDITY...10 to 15 percent.
* DETAILED URL...View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 21 at 1:45PM MDT by NWS Riverton WY
entry.summary:
The following message is transmitted on behalf of the Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, Air Quality Division, and the Wyoming Department of Health.
* WHAT...Air Quality Alert for Wildfire Smoke.
* WHERE...The Wind River Basin and portions of the Tetons and Wind River Mountains.
* WHEN...1 PM MDT Wednesday through 1 PM MDT Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Smoke from the Fish Creek Fire near Togwotee Pass will limit visibility and lead to poor air quality.
HEALTH INFORMATION...The Wyoming Department of Health recommends that the elderly, young children, and individuals with respiratory problems avoid excessive physical exertion and minimize outdoor activities during this time. Wildfire smoke is made up of a variety of pollutants, including particulate matter and ozone, which can cause respiratory health effects. Although these people are most susceptible to health impacts, the Department of Health also advises that everyone should avoid prolonged exposure to poor air quality conditions.
CURRENT CONDITIONS...The Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, Air Quality Division offers near real-time air quality data for Wyoming's monitoring stations and health effects information to help the public interpret current conditions. Current air quality conditions across the state of Wyoming can be found at http://www.wyvisnet.com/.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Teton and Gros Ventre Mountains; Jackson Hole; Upper Wind River Basin

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued August 21 at 12:43PM MDT until August 21 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS Rapid City SD
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM NOON TODAY TO 8 PM MDT THIS EVENING FOR GUSTY WINDS...LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY...AND DRY THUNDERSTORMS FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 321 AND 322...
High confidence in critical fire weather conditions developing across portions of northeastern Wyoming this afternoon. A very dry air mass will be over northeastern Wyoming and extreme southwestern South Dakota this afternoon with relative humidities ranging from 10 to 15 percent. Gusty southwest winds will develop through this afternoon with gusts of up to 30 mph possible. In addition, there is a chance for isolated thunderstorms to develop this afternoon, especially across southwestern South Dakota and the southern Black Hills. These storms may produce little to no rainfall. The combination of critically dry fuels, low relative humidities, gusty winds, and chances for dry thunderstorms will result in critical fire weather conditions.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 314 Northern Campbell, 315 Southern Campbell, 317 Weston County Plains, 321 Southern Black Hills and 322 Fall River County Area.
* WINDS...Southwest 10 to 20 mph with gusts up to 30 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 11 percent.
* IMPACTS...The combination of gusty winds and low relative humidity would produce critical fire weather conditions.
* LIGHTNING...Frequent cloud to ground lighting with little to no rainfall is expected.
* IMPACTS...The combination of gusty winds, low relative humidity, and dry lightning would produce critical fire weather conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Black Hills; Fall River County Area; Northern Campbell; Southern Campbell; Weston County Plains

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM MDT THIS EVENING FOR GUSTY WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 314, 315, 317, 321, AND 322

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 21 at 10:25AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary: A Bering Sea Low associated with the remnants of Typhoon Ampil, is moving north of St Lawrence Island and will move through the Bering Strait this afternoon. Strong southwest from the northwest this evening and overnight. This dynamic fetch will enhance the potential of coastal flooding along the West Coast south of the Bering Strait today into Thursday. Sea levels are expected to reach one to three feet above normal resulting in minor coastal flooding.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 21 at 2:24PM EDT until August 23 at 2:15PM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Madison County Emergency Management continues to report areas of flooding and gradually rising water across portions of Southeast Madison County. Areas of specific concern are near Lee Sink affecting SE Magnolia Drive as well as other flooded areas southward toward Interstate 10 and east of State Road 53. Flood waters are gradually shifting eastward toward the Suwannee River. Note that flood waters are not impacting access to or travel on Interstate 10 or US Highway 90.
* WHERE...A portion of Big Bend Florida in Southeast Madison County.
* WHEN...Until 215 PM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Numerous roads remain closed due to flooding. Expect many areas of slow moving or standing water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 215 PM EDT, Madison County Emergency Management reports continued flooding in the warned area. - Flooding will likely persist into at least early next week as water runoff from Hurricane Debby continues. With high groundwater levels, locations near small creeks, springs, or sinks in Southeast Madison County could be prone to flooding on relatively short notice. If you live in an area prone to flooding, take action to protect property. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Lee. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 20 at 3:28PM CDT by NWS New Orleans LA
entry.summary:
The Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality is forecasting an Ozone Advisory Day for East Baton Rouge, West Baton Rouge, Livingston, Ascension, Iberville, and Pointe Coupee Parishes on Wednesday.
The Air Quality Index indicates that ozone will be at the Orange level, which is unhealthy for sensitive groups. Increasing ozone levels may cause unhealthy air quality during afternoon hours. Active children and adults, the elderly, and people with respiratory diseases such as asthma should avoid prolonged outdoor exertion.
Please take whatever voluntary steps you can to reduce emissions that contribute to ozone formation. Drive less and make sure your automobile is in good working condition. Make sure your gas cap is tight. Wait until after 6 PM to refuel your vehicle and use gas powered lawn equipment. More information about current air quality and what you can do to help prevent ozone formation is available at the D E Q website www.deq.louisiana.gov/enviroflash or by calling 8 6 6 8 9 6 5 3 3 7.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Pointe Coupee; Iberville; West Baton Rouge; East Baton Rouge; Northern Livingston; Southern Livingston; Western Ascension; Eastern Ascension
